description: Ruby on Rails is a web development framework built upon the Ruby programming language. This series covers the basics of Ruby on Rails including but not limited to: what is Ruby on Rails, getting the environment set up, creating a simple web application the Ruby on Rails way, and diving a little deeper into the methodology used in a Rails application. If you are looking to get started with Ruby on Rails, then we will see you there!

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Manny explore the landscape of web development. Additionally, Manny describes the reason for using Ruby on Rails to create a dynamic website including the use of the Ruby programming language and use of the conventions that Rails uses.

WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

Greetings everyone and welcome to

3

I'm your host Justin Dennison and
we have a treat in store for you today.

4
00:00:20.031 --> 00:00:23.274
We are starting Ruby on Rails
in particular, in this episode,

5

we're gonna be talking about,
what is Ruby on Rails?

6

Now I'm no expert, but luckily we
have one in the studio with us today.

7
00:00:29.873 --> 00:00:32.030
Mr. Manny Rodriguez,
how you doing today, Manny?

8
00:00:32.030 --> 00:00:33.090
>> I'm doing great, Justin.

9
00:00:33.090 --> 00:00:34.580
It's great to be here.

10
00:00:34.580 --> 00:00:35.670
How are you doing?

11
00:00:35.670 --> 00:00:36.870
>> I'm doing fantastic, man.

12
00:00:36.870 --> 00:00:39.850
And actually I'm really excited because,

13
00:00:39.850 --> 00:00:44.180
I know kind of about the Ruby on Rails,
kind of aura.

14
00:00:44.180 --> 00:00:47.610
But, I don't really know
what is Ruby on Rails.

15
00:00:47.610 --> 00:00:53.760
So can you help reveal
the rails wonderfulness?

16
00:00:53.760 --> 00:00:59.270
>> Absolutely, so Ruby on Rails
is a web development framework.

17
00:00:59.270 --> 00:01:00.670
Now that's a lot of syllables.

18
00:01:00.670 --> 00:01:02.920
What does that actually mean,
a web development framework?

19
00:01:04.970 --> 00:01:12.060
A framework is a set of, it's a program
used to create other programs.

20
00:01:12.060 --> 00:01:17.066
Now, thinking about that on
the web we have apps on our phone,

21
00:01:17.066 --> 00:01:22.651
we have got websites we go to, and
sometimes maybe it's not entirely

22
00:01:22.651 --> 00:01:28.162
clear what is powering the programs
that we use on a day to day basis.

23
00:01:28.162 --> 00:01:33.096
By powering, I just mean
the technology that's running the show

24
00:01:33.096 --> 00:01:38.030
behind the scenes, that the programmer
is using to write logic or

25
00:01:38.030 --> 00:01:43.200
to draw pictures or
to make whatever's happening happen.

26
00:01:43.200 --> 00:01:46.510
So, on the web, we know,

27
00:01:46.510 --> 00:01:51.504
I've been online since 94, 95 and

28
00:01:51.504 --> 00:01:56.600
back then, websites were static,
they didn't move.

29
00:01:57.660 --> 00:02:04.270
And actually, not that they didn't move,
because you can scroll them,

30
00:02:04.270 --> 00:02:08.840
on your screen, but
the content didn't change at all.

31
00:02:08.840 --> 00:02:13.610
And I kind of have a website I'd
like to show you that shows this.

32
00:02:13.610 --> 00:02:21.140
Because it was pretty hard to find,
now in 2017, a website that static.

33
00:02:22.210 --> 00:02:25.910
>> Now is this your GeoCities
page from way back in the day, or

34
00:02:25.910 --> 00:02:28.270
am I getting a little too personal here?

35
00:02:28.270 --> 00:02:29.932
>> It sure looks like it, doesn't it?

36
00:02:29.932 --> 00:02:33.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Actually, Justin, I love dogs.

37
00:02:33.630 --> 00:02:38.685
And dachshunds are super,
super cute and I was looking for

38
00:02:38.685 --> 00:02:45.303
a static page, I happened to find one
related to dachshunds, so here we go.

39
00:02:45.303 --> 00:02:50.135
The reason why I'm bringing this
up is because on this site this

40
00:02:50.135 --> 00:02:52.058
page will never change.

41
00:02:52.058 --> 00:02:56.793
This is gonna stay the way it is for
all time, until you go in

42
00:02:56.793 --> 00:03:02.580
with an HTML editor and
actually change the text on your page.

43
00:03:02.580 --> 00:03:06.546
So that's why we call
this a static website.

44
00:03:06.546 --> 00:03:09.223
Two weeks from now,
if the webmaster hasn't updated it,

45
00:03:09.223 --> 00:03:13.630
I'm gonna come back here, it's gonna
look exactly the same as it does now.

46
00:03:13.630 --> 00:03:16.490
Now, if I hop on over to Google.

47
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:20.990
And just do a Google search,
maybe if I search for dachshunds.

48
00:03:22.280 --> 00:03:24.901
And already you'll notice
that things are happening.

49
00:03:24.901 --> 00:03:28.570
I started typing in the letters D-A-C-H,
and

50
00:03:28.570 --> 00:03:32.000
this whole search window popped up here.

51
00:03:32.000 --> 00:03:34.770

things I might wanna look for

52
00:03:34.770 --> 00:03:36.620
related to dachshunds.

53
00:03:36.620 --> 00:03:42.820
So this is a dynamic website and,
of course, if I execute this search.

54
00:03:42.820 --> 00:03:47.009
Then, I see a webpage, but
depending on what I type up here, so

55
00:03:47.009 --> 00:03:50.094
if I change my search
to dachshund miniature,

56
00:03:50.094 --> 00:03:55.256
now I've got a different set of search
results and the page looks different.

57
00:03:55.256 --> 00:03:59.460
So this is a dynamic website and
that's what Ruby on Rails is for, it's for

58
00:03:59.460 --> 00:04:01.264
creating dynamic websites, so

59
00:04:01.264 --> 00:04:04.850
that as programmers we can

60
00:04:04.850 --> 00:04:09.115
>> Now Manny, does Ruby on Rails
live within the browser or

61
00:04:09.115 --> 00:04:11.399

63
00:04:16.611 --> 00:04:22.501

64
00:04:22.501 --> 00:04:27.900
kind of like, hey would you like

65
00:04:27.900 --> 00:04:30.900
Kind of like that, and you think about
it and then a response comes back.

66
00:04:30.900 --> 00:04:34.170
It works very much the same
way with Ruby on Rails and

67
00:04:34.170 --> 00:04:37.200
other backend web technologies.

68
00:04:37.200 --> 00:04:42.940
So the code is actually not
running on the person's computer,

69
00:04:42.940 --> 00:04:44.330
on the client's computer.

70
00:04:44.330 --> 00:04:47.400
It's running on a server which

71
00:04:47.400 --> 00:04:49.250
>> Okay, I think I've got you now.

72
00:04:49.250 --> 00:04:52.300

73
00:04:52.300 --> 00:04:53.930
I've also heard speaking to you and

00:04:53.930 --> 00:04:56.800
to some other individuals

75
00:04:56.800 --> 00:05:02.144
Are dynamic websites and web

76
00:05:02.144 --> 00:05:03.960
>> That's an interesting question.

77
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:11.000
The way I think of it is that a dynamic

78
00:05:11.000 --> 00:05:15.960

79
00:05:15.960 --> 00:05:19.520
two and hit submit and it adds another

80
00:05:19.520 --> 00:05:25.587
Really, really simple, might be hard for

81
00:05:25.587 --> 00:05:28.633
But in terms of what it
actually is under the hood,

82
00:05:28.633 --> 00:05:33.140
it works pretty much under the same
principles that Facebook runs under.

83
00:05:34.410 --> 00:05:39.070
>> All right, so we're kind of
splitting hairs on semantics.

84
00:05:39.070 --> 00:05:40.930
Now, I do wanna back up a little bit.

85
00:05:40.930 --> 00:05:45.746
You talked about Ruby on Rail,
the static versus dynamic and you've shown

86
00:05:45.746 --> 00:05:50.497
us some wonderful examples, but
I've said a word a couple of times Ruby.

87
00:05:50.497 --> 00:05:55.077
Ruby and Rails is a frame work which we
are gonna get back to but what is Ruby,

88
00:05:55.077 --> 00:05:56.989
what's the Ruby part of that.

89
00:05:56.989 --> 00:06:01.033
>> Yeah, it's right there in
the name right, Ruby on Rails and

90
00:06:01.033 --> 00:06:06.050
in this community, they're used
synonymously, Ruby and Ruby on Rails.

91
00:06:06.050 --> 00:06:09.712
Many people think that if
you're referring to Rails,

92
00:06:09.712 --> 00:06:12.428
then Ruby on Rails like it's one thing.

93
00:06:12.428 --> 00:06:14.970
But actually, they're different.

94
00:06:14.970 --> 00:06:18.830
Ruby is a programming language,
a scripting language,

95
00:06:18.830 --> 00:06:23.180
that is used as a basis for Ruby on Rails.

96
00:06:23.180 --> 00:06:29.271
So Ruby on rails is one framework
that's written with the Ruby language,

97
00:06:29.271 --> 00:06:31.148
but there are others.

98
00:06:31.148 --> 00:06:33.013
Some of my favorites are Sinatra,

99
00:06:33.013 --> 00:06:37.735
which is basically a greatly reduced
simplified version of Ruby on Rails.

100
00:06:37.735 --> 00:06:41.350
And, I really enjoy using Ruby for
shell script editing as well.

101
00:06:42.400 --> 00:06:45.440
>> So Ruby is akin to Python or

102
00:06:45.440 --> 00:06:50.640
I guess to some extent JavaScript as
far as a scripting language it has some

103
00:06:50.640 --> 00:06:56.240
higher level principles built in,
it's not quite like bash scripting.

104
00:06:56.240 --> 00:06:59.760
But it's not a compiled language,
it's kind of a dynamic runtime, correct?

105
00:06:59.760 --> 00:07:02.400
>> Yes, that's right, that's right.

106
00:07:02.400 --> 00:07:05.450
It's cool that you've mentioned
Python because I feel like ruby and

107
00:07:05.450 --> 00:07:07.070
Python are very similar.

108
00:07:07.070 --> 00:07:14.431
As we get into the syntax of Ruby we'll
see that things like a white space,

109
00:07:14.431 --> 00:07:20.728
being well technically in Ruby
white space isn't important or

110
00:07:20.728 --> 00:07:28.251
it won't break the compiler like it
would in python, but it's very keen.

111
00:07:33.239 --> 00:07:37.343
And Ruby is object oriented,
just like Python is and

112
00:07:37.343 --> 00:07:40.500
Smalltalk and JavaScript as well.

113
00:07:40.500 --> 00:07:42.540
So yeah it shares a lot in
common with those languages.

114
00:07:42.540 --> 00:07:47.160
Especially the fact that
it's dynamically compiled.

115
00:07:47.160 --> 00:07:51.570
Well not compiled but it's dynamically
interpreted and it's object oriented.

116
00:07:51.570 --> 00:07:53.800
It's strongly object orientated.

117
00:07:53.800 --> 00:07:57.955
>> Well, I like that you threw Smalltalk
in there, that's a throwback for me.

118
00:07:57.955 --> 00:08:01.540
And so that I've done anything
other than I'm just playing around.

119
00:08:01.540 --> 00:08:04.888
Now, if you wanna move forward
on this framework thing,

120
00:08:04.888 --> 00:08:08.458
I do some frameworks
>> But can't we dive a little bit deeper

121
00:08:08.458 --> 00:08:14.470
into, I use a framework to build other
things, but why would I use a framework?

122
00:08:14.470 --> 00:08:15.870
>> Great question.

123
00:08:15.870 --> 00:08:20.800
So I'd like to draw a distinction
between a framework and the library.

124
00:08:20.800 --> 00:08:24.000
If you've done any kind of coding before,
you'll know that it's really,

125
00:08:24.000 --> 00:08:27.170
really great to be able to stand
on the shoulders of giants and

126
00:08:27.170 --> 00:08:28.840
use code that other people have written.

127
00:08:30.150 --> 00:08:35.208
So, if you want to write a game where
there's a ball bouncing around,

128
00:08:35.208 --> 00:08:39.924
it's so much more work to have to
write the physics of what happens

129
00:08:39.924 --> 00:08:43.560
when a ball hits a wall or
a ball hits another wall.

130
00:08:44.790 --> 00:08:46.398
So it's awesome when you find say,

131
00:08:46.398 --> 00:08:48.710
a physics library that
someone already wrote.

132
00:08:48.710 --> 00:08:54.170
You can just pull that into your code and
write your code against there's, and

133
00:08:54.170 --> 00:08:59.090
by leveraging existing resources, you get
to create something in the same amount of

134
00:08:59.090 --> 00:09:03.960
time that whatever amount of time that
you have, that's just way more effective.

135
00:09:05.560 --> 00:09:10.330
So a library is code that someone else
wrote that can be imported into your code.

136
00:09:10.330 --> 00:09:14.840
A framework operates under a similar
principle where we've got code

137
00:09:14.840 --> 00:09:19.415
that's written, that is intended
to be used by other programmers,

138
00:09:19.415 --> 00:09:23.830
but it kinda flips
the control a little bit.

139
00:09:23.830 --> 00:09:29.060
What I mean by control, is that when
you're using a library, you pretty much

140
00:09:29.060 --> 00:09:34.230
get to pick and choose where you use
the library and what the library does.

141
00:09:34.230 --> 00:09:36.750
When you're using a framework, however,

142
00:09:36.750 --> 00:09:41.070
the framework has little gaps in
it where you put your code and

143
00:09:41.070 --> 00:09:45.440
the framework establishes how
things are going to run, basically.

144
00:09:45.440 --> 00:09:50.360
So, I like to think of it as
a version of software Mad Libs,

145
00:09:50.360 --> 00:09:55.660
like those Mad Libs stories
where you have a story.

146
00:09:55.660 --> 00:10:01.768
I was going to the blank and I found
a blank, that kind of structure and

147
00:10:01.768 --> 00:10:05.682
frameworks allow you
to fill in those gaps.

148
00:10:05.682 --> 00:10:09.350
>> Okay, so it's kind of like we're
gonna provide you a template and

149
00:10:09.350 --> 00:10:11.904
then you just fill in
the pieces that explore or

150
00:10:11.904 --> 00:10:16.370
define the requirements that you have,
or your respective application.

151
00:10:16.370 --> 00:10:18.250
Now, I've used other frameworks, as well.

152
00:10:18.250 --> 00:10:22.410
I'm by no means a Ruby programmer, but
I've used flask and I've tinkered with

153
00:10:22.410 --> 00:10:26.910
Django which are both Python frameworks,
Express, things of that nature.

154
00:10:26.910 --> 00:10:32.050
I have tried Sinatra a little bit,
I tends to speak to my heart, but

155
00:10:32.050 --> 00:10:35.200
how does Ruby on Rails
compare to those others?

156
00:10:35.200 --> 00:10:36.710
>> Great question.

157
00:10:36.710 --> 00:10:43.510
Ruby on Rails, Sinatra, Express, those are
all back-end web development frameworks.

158
00:10:43.510 --> 00:10:46.724
And a little further into the series,
we'll talk about what that means.

159
00:10:46.724 --> 00:10:51.720
Back-end versus front-end and
where the pieces fall, but

160
00:10:51.720 --> 00:10:54.139
they basically accomplish the same tasks.

161
00:10:55.610 --> 00:11:00.480
The difference really is,
maybe one of aesthetics, maybe one of

162
00:11:02.030 --> 00:11:08.700
opinions, by opinions just software,
we wanna have the right tool for

163
00:11:08.700 --> 00:11:12.431
the job and different frameworks have
different strengths and weaknesses.

164
00:11:12.431 --> 00:11:17.480
In particular, Rails is cool, because
it allows you to prototype quickly and

165
00:11:17.480 --> 00:11:23.630
it makes really strong opinions, and
suggestions about how you should

166
00:11:23.630 --> 00:11:28.438
do things which can save you a lot of time
if you're trying to say you're a startup,

167
00:11:28.438 --> 00:11:33.050
and you wanna get your web app going
quickly and not spend a lot of time

168
00:11:33.050 --> 00:11:39.255
writing boilerplate, so that you can get
your demo up and show it to your partners.

169
00:11:39.255 --> 00:11:42.828
So in that sense, Rails, Express,

170
00:11:42.828 --> 00:11:47.789
there's a PHP framework
that's really similar to

171
00:11:47.789 --> 00:11:52.070
Rails called CakePHP and there's so many.

172
00:11:52.070 --> 00:11:55.740
There's so many frameworks
that do the same tasks, but

173
00:11:55.740 --> 00:11:57.580
kind of like what kind
of car do you drive?

174
00:11:59.730 --> 00:12:04.040
You can choose from several different
models, and they all have their pluses,

175
00:12:04.040 --> 00:12:07.280
and minuses even though they all
get you down the road as well.

176
00:12:07.280 --> 00:12:10.470
>> Well, hopefully,
this is not like my car.

177
00:12:10.470 --> 00:12:16.010
I gotta get that window fixed, but if you
had to sell me on Rails, if I was like

178
00:12:16.010 --> 00:12:21.900
I really like Flask, or I really like
Django, or I really like Express,

179
00:12:21.900 --> 00:12:25.220
or CakePHP, any of those and
there's a plethora of other ones.

180
00:12:25.220 --> 00:12:29.970
Pretty much every runtime or environment
has there on a web development frame.

181
00:12:29.970 --> 00:12:32.500
Actually, saw one for
Fortran, believe it or not.

182
00:12:32.500 --> 00:12:34.760
Those of you who have ever
experienced Fortran are like,

183
00:12:34.760 --> 00:12:36.110
I don't know how that would work.

184
00:12:36.110 --> 00:12:37.948
I don't either, but it exists.

185
00:12:37.948 --> 00:12:41.500
If you really had to sell me on Rails,
what would be my big takeaway?

186
00:12:41.500 --> 00:12:45.140
How would you get me to
jump on board with Rails?

00:12:45.140 --> 00:12:50.470
>> Well, Justin, let me get my salesmen
suit on and I gotta tell you that

188
00:12:50.470 --> 00:12:55.850
the great thing about Rails is, for me
personally, the Ruby programming language.

189
00:12:55.850 --> 00:13:00.590
It's such a sweat language to work with,
and it's expressive, and

190
00:13:00.590 --> 00:13:03.200
it's just fun to write code in Ruby.

191
00:13:03.200 --> 00:13:08.520
So be given that,
Rails has built on top of that really,

192
00:13:08.520 --> 00:13:11.160
really sweet foundation of Ruby and

193
00:13:11.160 --> 00:13:16.950
created an ecosystem where there's lots
of developers, there's lots of projects,

194
00:13:16.950 --> 00:13:23.230
there's a lot of packages and we're gonna
talk about packages later in the series.

195
00:13:23.230 --> 00:13:28.053
But basically, there's a huge community
of other growth developers using

00:13:28.053 --> 00:13:31.895
rails which makes you feel as
a developer supported in that,

00:13:31.895 --> 00:13:36.791
you're taking on this big project and
you've got a lot of features to write,

198
00:13:36.791 --> 00:13:40.178
and it's so nice to know that
others have your back and

199
00:13:40.178 --> 00:13:43.838
have written things that make
your job that much easier.

200
00:13:43.838 --> 00:13:48.676
>> So I'm gonna further pressure on that,
those do sound nice,

00:13:48.676 --> 00:13:53.141
but if you had to show me one
thing that exemplified that,

202
00:13:53.141 --> 00:13:56.506
that really sold me, what could you show?

203
00:13:56.506 --> 00:13:59.976
>> All right Justin,
well, great question and

204
00:13:59.976 --> 00:14:06.095
I gotta tell you that the community again,
it's key for me as a selling point for

205
00:14:06.095 --> 00:14:12.030
why Ruby on Rails is worth knowing,
worth learning, worth using.

206
00:14:12.030 --> 00:14:13.034
Let me show you what I mean.

00:14:13.034 --> 00:14:20.320
I'm gonna hop on over to rubygems.org,
which is a site that

shows the gems available that have been
written by the community at large.

00:14:27.472 --> 00:14:34.390
And we can see here,
we've got 8,860 total gems,

00:14:34.390 --> 00:14:40.190
code that people have written that
really encompasses anything that

00:14:40.190 --> 00:14:45.270
basically, what I'm getting at is if you
have a problem while you're developing

00:30:05.730 --> 00:30:07.810

00:31:17.770 --> 00:31:22.350
and we refresh this page.

00:31:30.050 --> 00:31:30.960
In our browser.

00:31:30.960 --> 00:31:33.860

00:31:33.860 --> 00:31:38.310

00:31:39.690 --> 00:31:41.620

00:31:51.060 --> 00:31:52.870

00:32:19.350 --> 00:32:20.610
Yeah, I forgot to write that.

00:33:00.140 --> 00:33:04.410

00:33:04.410 --> 00:33:07.810

00:33:09.130 --> 00:33:15.849

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Manny take a look at the data models that are necessary to persist data in the database. Manny explores the ActiveRecord ORM that is part of Ruby on Rails that provides some of the "magic" that is sometimes attributed to Rails as well as the migrations that are necessary to keep the data model and database in sync. Manny discusses the link between the controller and the model.
episodes.title: Intro to Rails Models

00:17:51.045 --> 00:17:56.660

a error, we can just drop out
of that I want another end here.

00:18:06.310 --> 00:18:07.200

00:18:40.490 --> 00:18:45.770

314
00:18:45.770 --> 00:18:46.810
And my message is here.

315
00:18:48.380 --> 00:18:51.670
Now, this is kind of a funny quirk or
rails, and some, see,

316
00:18:51.670 --> 00:18:54.970
sometimes all of this patterning and,

317
00:18:56.630 --> 00:18:59.550
the kind of way rails does things first,
at least the funny side effects.

318
00:18:59.550 --> 00:19:04.930
So, right now the aired message says Body
and then space, Can't say that word.

319
00:19:04.930 --> 00:19:09.400
And the reason why it's doing
that is because by default,

320
00:19:09.400 --> 00:19:12.220
the message appends the name of the field

321
00:19:12.220 --> 00:19:15.690
that the error is triggered on as
the first word in this message.

322
00:19:15.690 --> 00:19:20.450
So it kind of forces us to use
different language here for

323
00:19:20.450 --> 00:19:23.870
this error message to make sense, knowing
that the first word of it is going to be

324
00:19:23.870 --> 00:19:31.190
body because rail just enforces that So

325
00:19:31.190 --> 00:19:31.840
What do you think?

326

>> Well, Manny, I will definitely say

327

Again, I'm kind of torn

It's so easy that I wish I could do
it in every other time that I've

329
00:19:42.450 --> 00:19:43.960

330
00:19:43.960 --> 00:19:47.000
Now an immediate application
of this balderdash one.

331
00:19:47.000 --> 00:19:51.910
Is like a profanity, or

00:19:51.910 --> 00:19:54.540
Maybe not necessarily in your own post,

which we're definitely
gonna get to hopefully.

We're building a blog so

335
00:19:59.080 --> 00:20:02.670
So definitely stay tuned as we continue
looking into Ruby on Rails and

00:20:02.670 --> 00:20:03.570
see what's to come.

337
00:20:03.570 --> 00:20:06.090
But for this episode we're

00:20:06.090 --> 00:20:09.510

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

25

28
00:01:38.691 --> 00:01:43.842
So just off the bat, in general there's
three different types of relational

29
00:01:43.842 --> 00:01:48.450
relationships, and that's a whole
lot of relationships in there.

30
00:01:48.450 --> 00:01:53.336
Well, what I mean by that is that active
record is based on a relational of data

31
00:01:53.336 --> 00:01:53.871
model.

32

And in that,

33
00:01:54.487 --> 00:01:58.187

34
00:01:58.187 --> 00:02:00.433

35
00:02:00.433 --> 00:02:03.685
First, is one to one.

36
00:02:03.685 --> 00:02:08.207
So what that means is that
you've got a relationship

37
00:02:08.207 --> 00:02:12.639
where one of A has exactly one of B,
and vice versa.

38
00:02:12.639 --> 00:02:16.619
So maybe an example of that might be,
husband has one wife,

39
00:02:16.619 --> 00:02:18.939
a wife has one husband, you know?

40
00:02:18.939 --> 00:02:22.208
Now if you're into Robert Heinlein

00:02:22.208 --> 00:02:24.343
but this example we'll

42
00:02:24.343 --> 00:02:28.177
So what's going on here with
this one-to-one relationship?

43
00:02:28.177 --> 00:02:32.439
Let's say that we've got a database table,
our model.

44
00:02:32.439 --> 00:02:36.629
And we've got some attributes here,
like we'll kinda talk about with id and

45
00:02:36.629 --> 00:02:38.115

46
00:02:38.115 --> 00:02:40.295
But we've got first name,
we've got last name.

47
00:02:40.295 --> 00:02:42.956
We've got a gender, date of birth,
a favorite color, and

48
00:02:42.956 --> 00:02:44.776
then we've got this spouse_id thing.

49
00:02:44.776 --> 00:02:47.342
So again we're seeing this word id.

50
00:02:47.342 --> 00:02:48.928
So what's an id?

51
00:02:48.928 --> 00:02:54.799
We kinda saw a little bit of this
with the work we did last episode.

52
00:02:54.799 --> 00:02:55.747
We were looking at URLs.

53
00:02:55.747 --> 00:03:01.117
We were looking at the parameters pasting,

54
00:03:01.117 --> 00:03:05.848
Basically an id is a number or

55
00:03:05.848 --> 00:03:09.414

not just numbers in there.

56
00:03:09.414 --> 00:03:12.631
Or maybe SKU numbers if you're

57
00:03:12.631 --> 00:03:18.867
But it's data that uniquely

58
00:03:18.867 --> 00:03:23.372
So maybe social security number
could stand in here for id.

59
00:03:23.372 --> 00:03:26.332
Or if you work at a place

60
00:03:26.332 --> 00:03:30.015
Or you've got a school ID,
or something like that,

61
00:03:30.015 --> 00:03:34.469
it's basically a number that
definitely points towards you.

62
00:03:34.469 --> 00:03:41.138
So here, we've got this spouse id
thing going on here, what's that mean?

63
00:03:41.138 --> 00:03:47.638
And what this is, is this is a piece

64
00:03:47.638 --> 00:03:54.247
this people model, which holds the ID
of a spouse that this person has or

65
00:03:54.247 --> 00:03:59.007
maybe it could be blank if you're single,
right.

66
00:03:59.007 --> 00:04:03.976
So if this was implemented as a one to one
relationship, and it doesn't have to be

67
00:04:03.976 --> 00:04:07.937
it's just is an example that could
be a one to one relationship.

68
00:04:07.937 --> 00:04:13.634
Then we've got the ID, the primary key
which is a bit of jargon for you, but

69
00:04:13.634 --> 00:04:20.258
it basically means this ID represents this
particular model, an instance of a model.

70
00:04:20.258 --> 00:04:25.239
Whereas this spouse_id, both of these
names have the word id in them Bbut this

71
00:04:25.239 --> 00:04:30.456
is a foreign key, or it's data that points

72

>> Now, Manny,

00:04:32.636 --> 00:04:37.077

00:04:38.749 --> 00:04:43.128
This top person belongs

00:05:13.372 --> 00:05:16.581
That's really key for me,
it's whenever it's one to one, and

00:05:16.581 --> 00:05:18.909
there's one on this side and
one on this side.

00:05:18.909 --> 00:05:23.722
So maybe if I think of

00:05:23.722 --> 00:05:29.825

00:05:29.825 --> 00:05:34.163

00:05:34.163 --> 00:05:38.397

00:05:38.397 --> 00:05:43.277

right, where one person has one.

00:05:45.767 --> 00:05:46.867
That might not be a good example,

00:05:46.867 --> 00:05:48.646

00:05:48.646 --> 00:05:52.694
But if you were in a world where you were

00:05:52.694 --> 00:05:54.513

00:05:54.513 --> 00:05:58.193
>> And was kind of what I was
driving home, cuz a lot of times,

I have a hand, my hand belongs to me,

00:06:09.027 --> 00:06:11.154
So it seems to be a matter

00:06:11.154 --> 00:06:14.176

00:06:14.176 --> 00:06:17.482
But I didn't know if you had any insight

00:06:17.482 --> 00:06:22.099

00:06:22.099 --> 00:06:24.872

00:06:24.872 --> 00:06:27.063
>> Yeah.
>> So that's just one of those things

00:06:27.063 --> 00:06:28.252
where I don't know,

108
00:06:32.493 --> 00:06:34.175
>> Yeah, I completely agree.

00:06:34.175 --> 00:06:37.920
And I really appreciate the perspective

110
00:06:37.920 --> 00:06:39.914
There's a fair amount of
work that comes into that.

111
00:06:39.914 --> 00:06:42.864
Just coming up with the relationships

112
00:06:42.864 --> 00:06:46.242
Because although this is shown right now,
husband and

113
00:06:46.242 --> 00:06:50.662
wife as a one-to-one relationship,

00:06:50.662 --> 00:06:54.497

00:06:54.497 --> 00:06:59.260

00:06:59.260 --> 00:07:01.034

00:07:20.206 --> 00:07:23.403
right now we've got this

00:07:23.403 --> 00:07:27.213

00:07:27.213 --> 00:07:29.065

00:07:29.065 --> 00:07:33.706

rails this might be a good place for

00:07:33.706 --> 00:07:36.753

00:07:36.753 --> 00:07:39.740

00:07:39.740 --> 00:07:44.725

00:07:50.466 --> 00:07:53.298

00:07:55.830 --> 00:08:00.298
So here's we've got an example of a mother

00:08:00.298 --> 00:08:04.448

00:08:04.448 --> 00:08:06.572

00:08:06.572 --> 00:08:10.924

00:08:10.924 --> 00:08:12.557

137
00:08:12.557 --> 00:08:15.618
So this multiplicity only goes one way,

138
00:08:15.618 --> 00:08:20.676

139
00:08:20.676 --> 00:08:25.689
So kinda looking here at this example,
we've got the same

00:08:25.689 --> 00:08:30.203

attributes from before.

141
00:08:30.203 --> 00:08:35.155
But now we've added another attribute,
another foreign key called mother_id and

00:08:35.155 --> 00:08:38.096

143
00:08:38.096 --> 00:08:45.316
For this particular person, there

144
00:08:45.316 --> 00:08:49.821
But this model here doesn't
have any children, right.

145
00:08:49.821 --> 00:08:55.689
So this is really you can think of
it as also as one or zero to many,

146
00:08:55.689 --> 00:09:01.468

zero to one in the previous example.

147
00:09:01.468 --> 00:09:03.671
But in each case what do we see?

148
00:09:03.671 --> 00:09:09.509
We see that each person has
exactly one mother and only one.

149
00:09:09.509 --> 00:09:13.514
Even though as a person you
could have more than one child,

150
00:09:13.514 --> 00:09:15.648
you could have many children.

151
00:09:19.390 --> 00:09:22.733
So, where does that bring
us with many to many?

152
00:09:25.240 --> 00:09:29.304
And here, looking at what a many to
many relationship might look like,

153
00:09:29.304 --> 00:09:31.892
let's think about books and their authors.

154
00:09:31.892 --> 00:09:36.038
So an author writes a book and
a book has an author, so

155
00:09:36.038 --> 00:09:39.448
they could have a one to one relationship.

156
00:09:39.448 --> 00:09:41.463
Abut also a book could have many authors.

157
00:09:41.463 --> 00:09:43.462
So here, this book has two authors.

158
00:09:43.462 --> 00:09:46.233
We can see this arrow going
down to this author, and

159
00:09:46.233 --> 00:09:48.303
this arrow also going to this author.

160
00:09:48.303 --> 00:09:52.093
But an author can also write many books,
so

161
00:09:52.093 --> 00:09:57.375
this author wrote this book,
this author wrote this book.

162
00:09:57.375 --> 00:10:00.348
And this author, he only wrote this book.

163
00:10:00.348 --> 00:10:04.901
So we've got multiplicity on both sides,
where we have many people,

164
00:10:04.901 --> 00:10:06.763
many authors, many books.

165
00:10:06.763 --> 00:10:11.189
And they can be relate to each
other in any combination thereof.

166
00:10:13.559 --> 00:10:17.108
So how does this look in code,
or we're thinking about models,

167
00:10:17.108 --> 00:10:18.563
how do we represent that?

168
00:10:18.563 --> 00:10:23.390
And the answer is we use something
called a join table where we

169
00:10:23.390 --> 00:10:28.041
have another model that
represents their relationship.

170
00:10:28.041 --> 00:10:33.398
So here we've got the same
people model as before.

171
00:10:33.398 --> 00:10:37.120
You notice we haven't added
any more foreign keys to this.

172
00:10:37.120 --> 00:10:39.860
And we've got this books
model over here with id,

173
00:10:39.860 --> 00:10:44.379
title, description, publisher,
release date, data that represents a book.

174
00:10:44.379 --> 00:10:48.557
But we've got this third
Authorships model,

175
00:10:48.557 --> 00:10:52.314
and it links together a person and a book.

176
00:10:52.314 --> 00:10:55.531
And you can see that we can have many,
many rows of this.

177
00:10:55.531 --> 00:10:58.061
And this is how we get our
many to many relationship.

178
00:10:58.061 --> 00:11:03.198
So with this structure we can represent
something like a book having many authors.

179
00:11:03.198 --> 00:11:08.449
Or an author having a single book,
or an author writing many books.

180
00:11:08.449 --> 00:11:15.556
In this example here, this Book which show
up in this Authorship table twice, right.

181
00:11:15.556 --> 00:11:20.141
Because it's got, there's two Authorships,
one going this way, and

182
00:11:20.141 --> 00:11:22.635
one there, and it'll be there twice.
